awd_titl_txt: Understanding Storm-Time Electromagnetic Ion Cyclotron (EMIC) Wave Occurrences and Their Relationship to Ground Signatures
awd_abstract_narration:
The dynamics of the charged particles in the radiation belts has become an increasingly important science problem is recent years as society has become dependent on satellites in space. This is a project to investigate electromagnetic ion cyclotron waves (EMIC) in the space and their signatures on the ground. This project is well timed to support the NASA Van Allen Probes mission. It will support the work of a young scientist just starting his career.

Radiation belt particles can be heated, scattered and lost in their interaction with EMIC waves. The investigators will study the propagation characteristics of the waves as a function of geomagnetic activity and radiation belt dynamics. Since ground observations of the waves are much easier and cheaper than satellite observations being able to study them from the ground would be very useful. They will use GOES and THEMIS magnetic field data from space along with conjugate data from the ground in Antarctica  to address three questions: 1.) What is the relative occurrence of EMIC waves both in space and on the ground during each phase of a magnetic storm? 2.) Why are some of the waves not observed on the ground during certain phases (main and recovery) of the storm even though they are observed in space? 3.) How do heavy ions, He+ and O+, contribute to radiation belt precipitation losses and EMIC propagation to the ionosphere? This statistical study will be augmented by plasma data from LANL and THEMIS spacecraft.  Finally they will join with unfunded collaborators at PPPL who will carry out wave simulation studies using a two-dimensional finite element code. This part of the study will investigate attenuation of the waves by heavy ions.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit

Studying electromagnetic ion cyclotron (EMIC) wave occurrence and propagation during geomagnetic storms and substorms will help to understand radiation belt electron loss dynamics due to EMIC waves, which is important for developing space weather prediction models and has been of great interest within the space physics community.

The major goals of this project are to examine the relationship between EMIC wave occurrences in space and their ground signatures, and to understand EMIC wave propagation characteristics in relation to geomagnetic storm/substorm activity and radiation belt dynamics.

In this project, a variety of space- and ground-based instruments have been utilized to observe wave events and geospace environments to characterize the occurrences and propagation of the waves. Thanks to a number of space-ground conjunction multi-point observations, the team was able to reveal sptiotemporal extent of the wave activity associated with the coupled processes between the solar wind and magnetosphere. In addition, data from low altitude spacecraft and ground-based instruments such as auroral imagers and radars (e.g.,. SuperDARN and EISCAT) as well as ground-based magnetometer networks in both hemispheres helped understand how the waves affect the ionospheric and upper-atmospheric dynamics. Field and particle data from a spacecraft mission called Van Allen Probes have also been extensively utilized to reveal radiation belt electron scatter/loss processes due to EMIC waves associated with substorm injection events, one of the compelling scientific topics in the community. Such observations have been also supported by low altitude spacecraft and ground magnetometers. 

 

Broader impacts

The proposed work utilizes data sets provided by various projects sponsored by NASA and NSF. In particular, this project extensively used data from the ground magnetometer network, which is recognized as a cricital infrastructure for Geospace studies. As part of the project activities, ground-based search-coil magnetometers have been serviced and newly installed to enhance the capability of wave observations, providing important data for the broader community. Data from the instruments are now publicly available from the UNH website (http://mirl.unh.edu/cgi-bin/ulf.cgi).

This award supported the PI's research activities as an early career scientist who served as a postdoctoral fellow at Virginia Tech and a research scientist at New Jersey Institute of Technology, greatly helping him to be an indepedent scientist in the space science community. 

This project actively extensively engaged international institutions to promote synegistic scientific activities and cost-effiective instrument development and deployment. The PI has acted on behalf of University of New Hampshire (UNH) to help support the transfer of the induction coil magnetometer system design to collaborators in South Korea. This work is motivated by a mutual desire to strengthen collaborations among the PI’s institute (New Jersey Institute of Technology (NJIT)), UNH/Augsburg and Kyung Hee University (KHU) in South Korea and, at the same time, to expand the capability for observations of EMIC waves. As a result of the technology transfer, three search-coil magnetometers based on the UNH design are now deployed at the two Korean stations (Jang Bogo and King Sejong) and a German station (Neumayer III) in Antarctica. Jang Bogo is located near the US McMurdo station and ideally situated to provide complementary observations at a similar magnetic latitude and roughly 1 hour later in MLT. King Sejong is located near US Palmer Station. The PI visited S. Korea to supervise the KHU students for construction and test of the magnetometers. The magnetometers are now fully functional and producing scientifically significant data. The third search-coil magnetometer developed by KHU was installed at Neumayer Station run by Alfred-Wegener Institute (AWI). The PI of this project, Dr. Kim, visited AWI and GFZ in Germany under this grant to train the deploying team members for the magnetometer installation. The Neumayer magnetometer is now fully operational and provides high quality data (raw data and spectrograms are posted on the AWI data server). GFZ German Research Centre provides support for data archiving and quality checking.
